summary: The image appears to be a scientific paper or article that discusses the evolution of breast cancer from benign hyperplasia to invasive carcinoma. It mentions the role of sequence analysis in identifying specific genetic alterations associated with the development and progression of breast cancer, particularly in relation to histopathology features such as proliferative changes. The paper also refers to a human female breast cancer model and notes that mortality rates are higher for developing breast cancer compared to other forms of the disease.

Three of these engrafts became carcinomas. One (removed 7 weeks after transplantation} was an undifferentiated carcinoma composed of polygonal cells with large, vesicular nickel and numerous mitoses. The second (removed after 14 weeks) was an invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The third (removed after $6 weeks) was a moderately differentiated adencearcinoma, Initially, engrafts of MCFIGAneoT.TGI cells showed intraductal proliferative changes; after 23 weeks, the lesions showed normal of the national Cancer Institute, Vol. 5, No. 21, november 3, 1993 histologic features resembling these seen in atypical hyperplasia of te unman breast, and later tensions showed characteristics of carcinoma in situ. The MCFI0 lineage of cells of three MCFIAneoT-2G1 engrafts was confirmed my na fingerprinting and karyotype anal- ysis, Conclusions: MCFWAneot and MCFIOAneoT.TG1 comprise a translatable engraft model that produces a broad spectrum of human proliferative breast disease. Implications: The reproducible establishment of repre- tentative stages 1a early breast cancer progression from time MCF19 model offers a new opportunity to analyze critical events of carcinogenesis and progression in breast eamcer. [J nail Cancer Fast 85:1725-1732, 1993] Many hunan carcinomas evolve via a sequence from benign hyperplasia through atypical hyperplasia to carcinoma in sit and eventually to fully malignant, invasive tumors with the potential co metastasize. In the case of colorectal neoplasia, the well-recognized polyp-to-carcinomma sequence is associated with a series of specific genetic alterations (7) Although the colon cancer model has become a paradigm for solid tumor development, definition of critical genetic events in breast cancer has been hampered by the lengthy natural history, architectural complexity, and relative inaccessibility for sampling of breast cancers, particularly at the small, early stages. In the human female breast, a spectrum of pathologic change has been termed proliferative breast disease. The progression of histopathology features of proliferative breast disease has been associated with increased risk for the development of invasive carcinoma @). Women with the most severe form of proliferative breast disease, atypical hyperplasia, have a fourfold to fivefold increased relative risk of developing breast cancer. A series of human mammary epithelial cell lines has been derived at the Michigan Cancer Foundation from a woman with fibrocystic disease.
